<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Upon retirement or other disposal of property, plant&nbsp;&amp; equipment, the cost and related amount of
	accumulated depreciation are removed from the asset and accumulated depreciation accounts, respectively. The difference, if any, between the net asset value and the proceeds is included in operating income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Goodwill, Intangibles and Long-Lived Assets
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Goodwill is not amortized, but is instead tested for impairment at least annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate that it is more
	likely than not that they may be impaired. The Company has elected to perform the annual test for goodwill impairment as of October&nbsp;31 of each year. All goodwill has been allocated to the U.S. reporting unit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In performing tests for goodwill impairment, the Company is first permitted to perform a qualitative assessment about the likelihood of the
	carrying value of a reporting unit exceeding its fair value. If the Company determines that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount based on the qualitative assessment, it is required to
	perform the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	goodwill impairment test described below to identify the potential goodwill impairment and measure the amount of the goodwill impairment loss, if any, to be recognized for that reporting
	unit. However, if the Company concludes otherwise based on the qualitative assessment, the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	goodwill impairment test is not required. The option to perform the qualitative assessment is not an
	accounting policy election and can be utilized at the Company&#146;s discretion. Further, the qualitative assessment need not be applied to all reporting units in a given goodwill impairment test. For an individual reporting unit, if the Company
	elects not to perform the qualitative assessment, or if the qualitative assessment indicates that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then the Company must perform the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	goodwill impairment test for the reporting unit. If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value, then an impairment charge would be recorded.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In performing the annual goodwill impairment test in 2016 and 2015, the Company bypassed the option to perform a qualitative assessment and
	proceeded directly to performing the first step of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	goodwill impairment test.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company calculates the fair value of its reporting unit using the income approach and market approach using level 3 inputs. The income approach utilizes discounted forecasted future cash flows and the market approach utilizes fair value multiples of
	comparable publicly traded companies. The discounted cash flows are based on management&#146;s long-term financial projections as of the valuation date and are discounted using a risk adjusted rate of return, which is determined using estimates of
	market participant risk-adjusted weighted-average costs of capital and reflects the risks associated with achieving future cash flows. The market approach is
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	97
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage100"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	calculated using the guideline company method, where the Company uses market multiples derived from stock prices of companies engaged in the same or similar lines of business. There is not a
	quoted market price for the Company&#146;s reporting unit, therefore, a combination of the two methods is utilized to derive the fair value of the business. The Company evaluated and weighed the results of these approaches as well as ensures it
	understands the basis of the results of these two methodologies. The Company believes the use of these two methodologies ensures a consistent and supportable method of determining its fair value that is consistent with the objective of measuring
	fair value. If the fair value were to decline, then the Company may be required to incur material charges relating to the impairment of those assets. The Company completed its required annual impairment test for goodwill in the fourth quarter of
	2016 and determined that the fair value of the Company&#146;s reporting unit was substantially in excess of its carrying value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company tests intangible and long-lived assets for recoverability whenever events or changes in circumstances suggest that the carrying value of an asset or group of assets may not be recoverable. The Company measures the recoverability of assets to
	be held and used by comparing the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted net cash flows expected to be generated by the asset. If those assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment equals the amount by which the carrying amount
	of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets. Any impairments are recorded as permanent reductions in the carrying amount of the assets. Long-lived assets, other than goodwill and other intangible assets that are held for sale are recorded at
	the lower of the carrying value or the fair market value less the estimated cost to sell.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the first quarter of 2013, the Company
	executed a strategic shift in how it funds its research and development (&#147;R&amp;D&#148;) programs, which significantly altered the expected future costs and revenue associated with the Company&#146;s agents in development. Property,
	plant&nbsp;&amp; equipment dedicated to R&amp;D activities, which were impacted by the March 2013 R&amp;D strategic shift, have a carrying value of $2.9&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company believes these fixed assets will be
	utilized for either internally funded ongoing R&amp;D activities or R&amp;D activities funded by a strategic partner. If the Company is not successful in finding a strategic partner, and there are no alternative uses for those fixed assets, they
	could be subject to impairment in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Intangible assets, consisting of patents, trademarks and customer relationships related to
	the Company&#146;s products are amortized in a method equivalent to the estimated utilization of the economic benefit of the asset. Trademarks and patents are amortized on a straight-line basis, and customer relationships are amortized on an
	accelerated basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Contingencies
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	the normal course of business, the Company is subject to loss contingencies, such as legal proceedings and claims arising out of its business, that cover a wide range of matters, including, among others, product and environmental liability. The
	Company records accruals for those loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability will be incurred and the amount of loss can be reasonably estimated. The Company does not recognize gain contingencies until realized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Fair Values of Financial Instruments
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	estimated fair values of the Company&#146;s financial instruments, including its cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses approximate the carrying values of these instruments due to their short term
	nature. There are no assets measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The estimated fair value of the Company&#146;s Term Facility at both December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 approximates carrying value because the
	interest rate is subject to change with market interest rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Advertising and Promotion Costs
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Advertising and promotion costs are expensed as incurred. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, the Company incurred
	$3.6&nbsp;million, $3.1&nbsp;million and $2.8&nbsp;million, respectively in advertising and promotion costs, which are included in sales and marketing in the consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	98
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Research and Development
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Research and development costs are expensed as incurred and relate primarily to the development of new products to add to the Company&#146;s
	portfolio and costs related to its medical affairs and medical information functions. Nonrefundable advance payments for goods or services that will be used or rendered for future research and development activities are deferred and recognized as an
	expense as the goods are delivered or the related services are performed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Foreign Currency
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The consolidated statements of operations of the Company&#146;s foreign subsidiaries are translated into U.S. Dollars using net weighted
	average exchange rates. The net assets of the Company&#146;s foreign subsidiaries are translated into U.S. Dollars using the end of period exchange rates. The impact from translating the net assets of these subsidiaries at changing rates are
	recorded in the foreign currency translation adjustment account, which is included in accumulated other comprehensive loss in the consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Remeasurement of the Company&#146;s foreign currency denominated transactions are included in net income. For the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, losses arising from foreign currency transactions totaled approximately $0.9&nbsp;million, $1.8&nbsp;million and $0.3&nbsp;million, respectively. Transaction gains and losses are reported as a component of
	other income (expense), net in the consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Stock-Based Compensation
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date of the stock-based award based on the fair value of the award
	and is recognized as expense over the requisite service period, which generally represents the vesting period, and includes an estimate of the awards that will be forfeited. The Company uses the Black-Scholes valuation model for estimating the fair
	value of stock options. The fair value of stock option awards is affected by the valuation assumptions, including the expected volatility based on comparable market participants, expected term of the option, risk-free interest rate and expected
	dividends. When a contingent cash settlement of vested options becomes probable, the Company reclassifies its vested awards to a liability and accounts for any incremental compensation cost in the period in which the settlement becomes probable.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Comprehensive Income (Loss)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Comprehensive income consists of net income and other gains and losses affecting stockholders&#146; equity that, under U.S. GAAP, are excluded
	from net income. For the Company, such items consist primarily of foreign currency translation gains and losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Asset Retirement Obligations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s compliance with federal, state, local and foreign environmental laws and regulations may require it to remove or mitigate
	the effects of the disposal or release of chemical substances in jurisdictions where
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	99
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage102"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	it does business or maintains properties. The Company establishes accruals when those costs are legally obligated and probable and can be reasonably estimated. Accrual amounts are estimated based
	on currently available information, regulatory requirements, remediation strategies, historical experience, the relative shares of the total remediation costs and a relevant discount rate, when the time periods of estimated costs can be reasonably
	predicted. Changes in these assumptions could impact the Company&#146;s future reported results.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Self-Insurance Reserves
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheets at both December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 include $0.4&nbsp;million of accrued liabilities
	associated with employee medical costs that are retained by the Company. The Company estimates the required liability of those claims on an undiscounted basis based upon various assumptions which include, but are not limited to, the Company&#146;s
	historical loss experience and projected loss development factors. The required liability is also subject to adjustment in the future based upon changes in claims experience, including changes in the number of incidents (frequency) and change in the
	ultimate cost per incident (severity). The Company also maintains a separate cash account to fund these medical claims and must maintain a minimum balance as determined by the plan administrator. The balance of this restricted cash account was
	approximately $0.1&nbsp;million at both December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, and is included in other current assets.
</P>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP" COLSPAN="7">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Recently Issued Accounting Standards Not Yet Adopted
</I>
</B>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	ASU&nbsp;2016-15,
</FONT>
<I>
	&nbsp;Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification&nbsp;of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments
</I>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	This standard addresses the presentation and classification of eight specific cash flow issues, including debt prepayment and extinguishment costs. Early adoption is permitted, including adoption in an interim period. Adoption is
	required on a retrospective basis unless it is impracticable to apply, in which case the amendments for those issues are to be applied prospectively as of the earliest date practicable.
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2018
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not expect the update to have
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	a
	material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09,
</FONT>
<I>
	Compensation&#151;Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting
</I>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	simplifies several aspects of the stock compensation guidance in Topic 718 and other
	related guidance providing the following amendments:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Accounting for income taxes upon vesting or exercise of share-based payments and related
	EPS effects
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Classification of excess tax benefits on the statement of cash flows
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Accounting for
	forfeitures
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liability classification exception for statutory tax withholding requirements
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow
	presentation of employee taxes paid when an employer withholds shares for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-withholding
</FONT>
	purposes
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Elimination of the indefinite deferral in Topic 718.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For public business entities, the amendments are effective for annual periods beginning
	after December&nbsp;15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	January&nbsp;1, 2017
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company does not expect the update to have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-02,
</FONT>
<I>
	Leases (Topic 842)
</I>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	This ASU supersedes existing guidance on accounting for leases in &#147;Leases (Topic 840)&#148; and generally requires all leases to be recognized in the statement of financial position. The provisions of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-02
</FONT>
	are effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2018; early adoption is permitted. The provisions of this ASU are to be applied using a modified retrospective approach.
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	January&nbsp;1, 2019
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company is currently assessing the impact that this standard will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_CASH_FLOW>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_28"></A>
<B>
	Standard
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Description
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Effective Date
<BR>
	for Company
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Effect on the
<BR>
	Consolidated&nbsp;Financial
<BR>
	Statements
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT" BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD HEIGHT="5">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2014-09,
</FONT>
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606)
</I>
	and related additional amendments ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2015-14,
</FONT>
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-08,
</FONT>
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-10,
</FONT>
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-11,
</FONT>
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-12
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This ASU and related amendments affect any entity that either enters into contracts with customers to transfer goods or services or enters
	into contracts for the transfer of nonfinancial assets, unless those contracts are within the scope of other standards. The guidance in this ASU supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in Topic 605, Revenue Recognition and most
	industry-specific guidance. The core principle of the guidance is that an entity should recognize revenue upon the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be
	entitled in exchange for those goods or services. The new guidance also includes a set of disclosure requirements that will provide users of financial statements with comprehensive information about the nature, amount, timing, and uncertainty of
	revenue and cash flows arising from a reporting organization&#146;s contracts with customers. In August 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-14,
</FONT>
	&#147;Revenue from Contracts
	with Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date,&#148; which defers the effective date of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2014-09
</FONT>
	by one year. This ASU is effective for annual reporting periods, and interim periods within
	those years, beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017 for public companies and permits the use of either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method, with early adoption permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after
	December&nbsp;15, 2016, including interim reporting periods within those annual periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The standard is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017, and interim periods therein, using either of the following
	transition methods:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A full retrospective approach reflecting the application of the standard in each prior
	reporting period with the option to elect certain practical expedients, or
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.50EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.50EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A retrospective approach with the cumulative effect of initially adopting ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2014-09
</FONT>
	recognized at the date of adoption (which includes additional footnote disclosures).
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	January&nbsp;1, 2018
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company is currently evaluating the impact the adoption of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2014-09
</FONT>
	on its consolidated financial statements and has not yet determined the method by which it will adopt the standard in
	2018.
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT">
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="7">
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	Accounting Standards Adopted During the Year Ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016
</I>
</B>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT" BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">

</TD>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2015-17,
</FONT>
<I>
	Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes
</I>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	During the first quarter of 2016, the Company early adopted ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-17,
</FONT>
	Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes on a retrospective basis. This
	standard requires all deferred taxes and liabilities, and any related valuation allowances, to be classified as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-current
</FONT>
	on the balance sheet.
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	January&nbsp;1, 2016
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	Adoption of this standard resulted in the reclassification of $0.1&nbsp;million of current deferred tax assets to noncurrent deferred tax assets and $0.2&nbsp;million of current deferred tax liabilities to noncurrent deferred tax
	liabilities on the accompanying consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT">
<TD HEIGHT="5">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2014-15,
</FONT>
<I>
	Presentation of Financial Statements&#151;Going Concern (Subtopic
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	205-40):
</FONT>
	Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity&#146;s Ability to
	Continue as a Going Concern
</I>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	This ASU requires management to evaluate whether there are conditions or events that raise substantial doubt about the entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern within one year after the date that the financial statements
	are issued. The ASU is effective for annual reporting periods (including interim reporting periods within those periods) ending after December&nbsp;15, 2016.
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	The adoption of this standard did not have a material impact on the presentation of the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	101
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	3. Financial Instruments and Fair Value Measurements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between
	market participants at the measurement date. In order to increase consistency and comparability in fair value measurements, financial instruments are categorized based on a hierarchy that prioritizes observable and unobservable inputs used to
	measure fair value into three broad levels, which are described below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Level 1
</I>
	&#151; Inputs are unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company has the ability to access at the measurement date.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Level 2
</I>
	&#151; Inputs include quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active, inputs other than
	quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability (i.e., interest rates, yield curves, etc.) and inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means (market corroborated
	inputs).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Level 3
</I>
	&#151; Unobservable inputs that reflect a Company&#146;s estimates about the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability. The Company develops these inputs based on
	the best information available, including its own data.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the Company&#146;s financial
	assets that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis are comprised of money market securities and are classified as cash equivalents. The Company invests excess cash from its operating cash accounts in overnight investments and reflects these
	amounts in cash and cash equivalents on the consolidated balance sheet using quoted prices in active markets for identical assets (Level 1).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The tables below present information about the Company&#146;s assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_30"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="7%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="7%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="7%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="7%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="14" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
	December&nbsp;31, 2016
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" NOWRAP>
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000; WIDTH:48.60PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	(in thousands)
</B>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total&nbsp;Fair&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	Value
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">
<B>
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(Level&nbsp;1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">

</B>
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(Level&nbsp;3)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Money market
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3,565

	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage106"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s provision for income taxes in the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and
	2014 was different from the amount computed by applying the statutory U.S. Federal income tax rate to income (loss) from operations before income taxes, as a result of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:3.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Lapse of statute of limitations
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	(416
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	)&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX; ">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:1.00PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:1.00PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Balance of uncertain tax positions as of December&nbsp;31, 2016
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	$
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;10,441
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits was $10.4&nbsp;million
	and $11.5&nbsp;million, respectively, all of which would affect the effective tax rate, if recognized. These amounts are primarily associated with domestic state tax issues, such as the allocation of income among various state tax jurisdictions and
	transfer pricing.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, total liabilities for tax obligations and associated interest and penalties were
	$34.4&nbsp;million and $33.8&nbsp;million, respectively, consisting of income tax provisions for uncertain tax benefits of $10.4 million and $11.7 million, interest accruals of $21.9&nbsp;million and $19.9&nbsp;million, and penalty accruals of
	$2.1&nbsp;million and $2.2 million, respectively. As of December 31, 2016 and 2015, $33.2&nbsp;million and $32.9&nbsp;million, respectively, were included in other long-term liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets and $1.2 million and
	$0.9&nbsp;million, respectively have reduced the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets. Included in the 2016, 2015 and 2014 tax provision is $2.0&nbsp;million, $2.5&nbsp;million and $1.2&nbsp;million, respectively, relating to interest and penalties,
	net of benefits for reversals of uncertain tax position interest and penalties recognized upon settlements and lapse of statute of limitations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In accordance with the Company&#146;s acquisition of the medical imaging business from Bristol Myers Squibb (&#147;BMS&#148;) in 2008, the
	Company obtained a tax indemnification agreement with BMS related to certain tax obligations arising prior to the acquisition of the Company, for which the Company has the primary legal obligation. The tax indemnification receivable is recognized
	within other noncurrent assets. The total noncurrent asset related to the indemnification was $17.9&nbsp;million and $17.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. The changes in the tax indemnification asset are recognized
	within other income (expense), net, in the consolidated statement of operations. In accordance with the Company&#146;s accounting policy, the change in the tax liability and penalties and interest associated with these obligations (net of any
	offsetting federal or state benefit) is recognized within the tax provision. Accordingly, as these reserves change, adjustments are included in the tax provision while the offsetting adjustment is included in other income (expense), net. Assuming
	that the receivable from BMS continues to be considered recoverable by the Company, there will be minimal net effect on earnings and net cash outflows related to these liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, BMS, on behalf of the Company, made payments totaling $0.7&nbsp;million,
	$1.9&nbsp;million and $6.3&nbsp;million, respectively to a number of states in connection with prior year state income tax filings. The amount due from BMS, included within other long-term assets, decreased by $1.3&nbsp;million, $1.6&nbsp;million
	and $2.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively, which represented the release of asset balances associated with
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-acquisition
</FONT>
	years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	105
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage108"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in other income (expense), net for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and
	2014, is an expense of $0.8&nbsp;million, $0.4&nbsp;million and $1.1&nbsp;million, respectively, relating to the reduction in the indemnification receivable from BMS associated with the expiration of statute of limitations and income of
	$1.8&nbsp;million, $2.1&nbsp;million and $1.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively, relating to the increase in the indemnification receivable for current year interest and penalties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company regularly assesses its ability to realize its deferred tax assets. Assessing the realization of deferred tax assets requires
	significant management judgment. In determining whether its deferred tax assets are more likely than not realizable, the Company evaluated all available positive and negative evidence, and weighted the evidence based on its objectivity. Evidence the
	Company considered included its history of net operating losses, which resulted in the Company recording a full valuation allowance for domestic deferred tax assets in 2011 and each year thereafter. The Company was profitable on a cumulative basis
	for the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, but substantially all of that profitability was achieved during 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company
	continues to evaluate other negative evidence including customer concentration and contractual risk, the risk of Moly supply availability and cost, DEFINITY supplier risk and certain product development risks, all of which provide for uncertainties
	around the Company&#146;s future level of profitability. Based on the review of all available evidence, the Company determined that it has not yet attained a sustained level of profitability and the objectively verifiable negative evidence
	outweighed the positive evidence and it has recorded a valuation allowance to reduce its deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realizable as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company will continue to assess the level of
	the valuation allowance required. If sufficient positive evidence exists in future periods to support a release of some or all of the valuation allowance, such a release would likely have a material impact on the Company&#146;s results of
	operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is a reconciliation of the Company&#146;s valuation allowance for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015,
	and 2014.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s U.S. federal income tax returns remain subject to examination for three years. The state
	and foreign income tax returns remain subject to examination for periods varying from three to four years depending on the specific jurisdictions&#146; statute of limitations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has federal net operating loss carryovers of $200.3&nbsp;million, which will begin to expire in 2030
	and completely expire in 2036. The Company has state research credits of $1.6&nbsp;million, which will expire between 2024 and 2031. The Company has Massachusetts investment tax credits of approximately $0.4&nbsp;million, which have no expiration
	date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	106
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage109"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has concluded that an ownership change occurred during 2016, as defined under
	Section&nbsp;382 of the Internal Revenue Code. A Section&nbsp;382 limitation now applies to the Company&#146;s U.S. federal net operating loss carryforwards, as well as its other U.S. tax attributes. The limitation was computed based on the value of
	the Company just prior to the ownership change. It is the Company&#146;s view that its ability to utilize U.S. federal net operating losses within the carryforward period is not reduced by the limitation imposed by this ownership change. However,
	the Company&#146;s U.S. research credit carryforwards and U.S. foreign tax credit carryforwards will not be utilizable and as such these credits totaling $7.1&nbsp;million have been removed from the gross deferred tax asset balances as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	5. Sales of Certain International Segment Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sale of Certain Canadian Assets
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During
	the fourth quarter of 2015, the Company committed to a plan to sell certain assets and liabilities associated with the Company&#146;s Canadian operations in the International Segment. This event qualified for held for sale accounting and the Company
	determined that the fair value of the net assets being sold significantly exceeded the carrying value as of December&nbsp;31, 2015. The transaction was finalized in the first quarter of 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Effective January&nbsp;7, 2016, the Canadian subsidiary of the Company entered into an asset purchase agreement (&#147;Canadian Asset Purchase
	Agreement&#148;) pursuant to which it would sell substantially all of the assets of its Canadian radiopharmacy businesses and Gludef manufacturing and distribution business to one of its existing Canadian radiopharmacy customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The purchase price for the asset sale was $9.0&nbsp;million in cash and also included a working capital adjustment of $0.5&nbsp;million, which
	was settled in the third quarter of 2016. The Canadian Asset Purchase Agreement contained customary representations, warranties and covenants by each of the parties. Subject to certain limitations, the buyer will be indemnified for damages resulting
	from breaches or inaccuracies of the Company&#146;s representations, warranties and covenants in the Canadian Asset Purchase Agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the transaction, the Company and the buyer also entered into a customary transition services agreement and a long-term supply
	contract under which the Company will supply the buyer with certain of the Company&#146;s products on commercial terms and under which the buyer has agreed to certain product minimum purchase commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not believe the sale of certain net assets in the international segment constituted a strategic shift that would have a major
	effect on its operations or financial results. As a result, this transaction is not classified as discontinued operations in the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements and the Company has classified the assets and liabilities as held for
	sale as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	107
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage110"></A>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This sale of assets resulted in a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	book gain of
	$5.9&nbsp;million, which is recorded within gain on sales of assets in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sale of Australian Radiopharmacy Servicing Subsidiary
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Effective August&nbsp;11, 2016, the Company entered into a share purchase agreement (&#147;Australian Share Purchase Agreement&#148;) with one
	of its existing radiopharmacy customers under which it sold all of the stock of its Australian radiopharmacy servicing subsidiary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	aggregate share sale price was AUD $2.0&nbsp;million (approximately $1.5 million) in cash and also included a working capital adjustment of approximately AUD $2.0&nbsp;million (approximately $1.5 million) for total expected proceeds of AUD
	$4.0&nbsp;million (approximately $3.0 million) from the sale. As a result of this sale, the Company disposed of net assets of $2.2&nbsp;million, primarily comprised of working capital accounts of $2.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This share sale resulted in an adjusted
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	book gain of $0.5&nbsp;million, which is recorded
	within gain on sales of assets in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.&nbsp;As a result of the sale of the Australian subsidiary, the Company reclassified $0.4&nbsp;million from other
	comprehensive income to gain on sale of assets in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Australian Share Purchase Agreement contains customary representations, warranties and covenants by each of the parties. Subject to
	certain limitations, the buyer will be indemnified for damages resulting from breaches or inaccuracies of the Company&#146;s representations, warranties and covenants in the Australian Share Purchase Agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the transaction, the Company and the buyer also entered into a long-term supply and distribution contract under which the Company
	will supply the buyer and its subsidiaries with the Company&#146;s products on commercial terms and under which the buyer has agreed to certain product minimum purchase commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not believe this sale of certain net assets in the international segment constituted a strategic shift that would have a
	major effect on its operations or financial results. As a result, this transaction is not classified as discontinued operations in the Company&#146;s accompanying consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	108
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Depreciation and amortization expense related to property, plant&nbsp;&amp; equipment was $12.1&nbsp;million,
	$12.9&nbsp;million and $10.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included within
	machinery, equipment and fixtures are spare parts of approximately $2.4&nbsp;million at both December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015. Spare parts include replacement parts relating to plant&nbsp;&amp; equipment and are either recognized as an expense when
	consumed or reclassified and capitalized as part of the related asset and depreciated over the remaining useful life of the related asset.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, $0.6&nbsp;million and $7.9&nbsp;million, respectively, of capitalized software
	development costs were placed into service and removed out of construction in progress.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Long-Lived Assets to Be Disposed of Other than by Sale
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In December 2016, the Company approved plans to decommission certain long-lived assets associated with its North Billerica,
	Massachusetts campus. The Company expects the decommissioning to begin in the first half of 2017.&nbsp;As a result, the Company revised its estimate of the remaining useful lives of the affected long-lived assets to six months, which resulted in the
	recognition of accelerated depreciation expense of $0.8&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, which has been included in research and development expense in the consolidated statements of operations.&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31,
	2016, the net book value of these assets totaled $4.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	109
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage112"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	8. Asset Retirement Obligations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company considers the legal obligation to remediate its facilities upon a decommissioning of its radioactive related operations as an asset
	retirement obligation. The operations of the Company have radioactive production facilities at its North Billerica, Massachusetts and San Juan, Puerto Rico sites.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is required to provide the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission and Massachusetts Department of Public Health financial assurance
	demonstrating the Company&#146;s ability to fund the decommissioning of the North Billerica, Massachusetts production facility upon closure, although the Company does not intend to close the facility. The Company has provided this financial
	assurance in the form of a $28.2&nbsp;million surety bond, which is secured by an $8.8&nbsp;million unfunded Standby Letter of Credit provided to the third party issuer of the bond.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of a liability for asset retirement obligations is recognized in the period in which the liability is incurred. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the liability is measured at the present value of the obligation expected to be incurred, of approximately $26.9&nbsp;million, and is adjusted in subsequent periods as accretion expense is recorded. The corresponding asset
	retirement costs are capitalized as part of the carrying values of the related property, plant&nbsp;&amp; equipment and depreciated over the assets&#146; useful lives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is a reconciliation of the Company&#146;s asset retirement obligations:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	$6.0&nbsp;million and $7.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	11. Financing Arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Term Facility
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;30, 2015, LMI
	entered into a new $365.0&nbsp;million seven-year Term Facility, which was issued net of a 1.25% discount of $4.6&nbsp;million. LMI has a right to request an increase of the Term Facility in an aggregate amount up to $37.5&nbsp;million plus
	additional amounts subject to certain leverage ratios. The net proceeds of the Term Facility, together with the net proceeds of the IPO and cash on hand, were used to refinance in full the aggregate principal amount of the Notes and pay related
	premiums, interest and expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The term loans under the Term Facility bear interest, with pricing based from time to time at LMI&#146;s
	election at (i)&nbsp;LIBOR plus a spread of 6.00% (with a LIBOR rate floor of 1.00%) or (ii)&nbsp;the Base Rate (as defined in the Term Facility Agreement) plus a spread of 5.00%. Interest under term loans based on (i)&nbsp;the LIBOR rate is payable
	at the end of each interest period (as defined in the Term Facility Agreement) and (ii)&nbsp;the Base Rate is payable at the end of each quarter. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s interest rate under the Term Facility was 7.00%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	LMI is permitted to voluntarily prepay the Term Facility, in whole or in part, with a premium applicable for the first six months of the Term
	Facility in connection with a repricing transaction. LMI is required to make quarterly payments, which began on September&nbsp;30, 2015, in an amount equal to a quarter of a percent (0.25%) per annum of the original principal amount of the Term
	Facility. The remaining unpaid principal amount of the Term Facility will be payable on the maturity date, or June&nbsp;30, 2022.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	111
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Term Facility will require LMI to prepay outstanding term loans, subject to certain
	exceptions, with:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	100% of the net cash proceeds of related to sales outside the ordinary course of business or other dispositions of assets (including as a result of casualty or condemnation, subject to certain exceptions); the Company
	may reinvest or commit to reinvest certain of those proceeds in assets useful in its business within 12 months;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	100% of the net cash proceeds from issuances or incurrence of debt, other than proceeds from debt permitted under the Term Facility and Revolving Facility;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	50% (with two leverage-based stepdowns) of the Company&#146;s excess cash flow; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	50% of net payments from the Zurich insurance settlement (as defined therein).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The foregoing
	mandatory prepayments will be applied to the scheduled installments of principal of the Term Facility in direct order of maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Term Facility is guaranteed by the Company and Lantheus Real Estate, and obligations under the Term Facility are secured by substantially all the assets and all interests of the Company, LMI and Lantheus Real Estate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In September and November 2016, the Company made aggregate voluntary prepayments on the Term Facility of $75.0&nbsp;million with the net
	proceeds to the Company of $48.8&nbsp;million received from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	follow-on
</FONT>
	underwritten offerings of the Company&#146;s common stock and approximately $26.2&nbsp;million from available cash on hand.&nbsp;These
	voluntary prepayments each represented a partial extinguishment of the Term Facility. Accordingly, the Company wrote off $1.9&nbsp;million of unamortized debt issuance costs and original issue discount, which are reflected as debt retirement costs
	in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s minimum payments of principal obligations under the Term
	Facility are as follows as of December&nbsp;31, 2016:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Term Facility Covenants
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Term Facility contains a number of affirmative, negative, reporting and financial covenants, in each case subject to certain exceptions and
	materiality thresholds. The Term Facility requires the Company to be in quarterly compliance, measured on a trailing four quarter basis. The financial covenants are displayed in the table below:
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_47"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	Term Facility Financial Covenants
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="68%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">

</TD>

<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000; WIDTH:22.65PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Term Facility contains usual and customary restrictions on the ability of the Company and its subsidiaries
	to: (i)&nbsp;incur additional indebtedness (ii)&nbsp;create liens; (iii)&nbsp;consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; (iv)&nbsp;sell certain assets; (v)&nbsp;pay dividends on, repurchase or make
	distributions in respect of capital stock or make other restricted payments; (vi)&nbsp;make certain investments; (vii)&nbsp;repay subordinated indebtedness prior to stated maturity; and (viii)&nbsp;enter into certain transactions with its
	affiliates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Senior Notes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	LMI had
	$400.0&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding. The interest on the Notes was at a rate of 9.750%&nbsp;per year, payable on May&nbsp;15 and November&nbsp;15 of each year. The net proceeds of the Term Facility, together
	with the net proceeds of the IPO and cash on hand, were used to refinance in full the aggregate principal amount of the Notes and pay related premiums, interest and expenses. The Company satisfied and discharged its obligations under the Notes as of
	June&nbsp;30, 2015. The notes and accrued interest were redeemed in full on July&nbsp;30, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded a loss on
	extinguishment of debt totaling $15.5&nbsp;million, which included a redemption premium of $9.7&nbsp;million and a $5.8&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unamortized debt issuance costs associated with the Senior
	Notes. On June&nbsp;30, 2015, the Company also paid the accrued interest to the redemption date totaling $3.3&nbsp;million, which is included in interest expense for the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 on the consolidated statements of
	operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Revolving Line of Credit
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, LMI has a Revolving Facility with an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $50.0&nbsp;million. The loans under
	the Revolving Facility bear interest subject to a pricing grid based on average historical excess availability, with pricing based from time to time at the election of LMI at (i)&nbsp;LIBOR plus a spread ranging from 2.00% or (ii)&nbsp;the Reference
	Rate (as defined in the agreement) plus 1.00%. The Revolving Facility also includes an unused line fee of 0.375% and expires on June&nbsp;30, 2020.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has an unfunded Standby Letter of Credit of $8.8&nbsp;million. The unfunded Standby Letter of Credit
	requires an annual fee, payable quarterly, which is set at LIBOR plus a spread of 2.00% and expired during February 2017. It automatically renewed for a one year period and will continue to automatically renew for a one year period at each
	anniversary date, unless the Company elects not to renew in writing within 60 days prior to such expiration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Revolving Facility is
	guaranteed by Holdings and Lantheus Real Estate and is secured by a pledge of substantially all of the assets of each of the loan parties including accounts receivable, inventory and machinery
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	113
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage116"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D269039D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	and equipment. Borrowing capacity is determined by reference to a Borrowing Base, which is based on a percentage of certain eligible accounts receivable, inventory and machinery and equipment
	minus any reserves. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the aggregate Borrowing Base was approximately $44.6&nbsp;million, which was reduced by an outstanding $8.8&nbsp;million unfunded Standby Letter of Credit and $0.1&nbsp;million in accrued interest,
	resulting in a net Borrowing Base availability of approximately $35.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Revolving Line of Credit Covenants
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Revolving Facility contains affirmative and negative covenants, as well as restrictions on the ability of the Company and its subsidiaries
	to: (i)&nbsp;incur additional indebtedness or issue preferred stock; (ii)&nbsp;repay subordinated indebtedness prior to its stated maturity; (iii)&nbsp;pay dividends on, repurchase or make distributions in respect of capital stock or make other
	restricted payments; (iv)&nbsp;make certain investments; (v)&nbsp;sell certain assets; (vi)&nbsp;create liens; (vii)&nbsp;consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; and (viii)&nbsp;enter into certain
	transactions with its affiliates. The Revolving Facility also contains customary default provisions as well as cash dominion provisions which allow the lender to sweep its accounts during the period certain specified events of default are continuing
	under the Revolving Facility or excess availability under the Revolving Facility falls below (i)&nbsp;the greater of $7.5&nbsp;million or 15% of the then-current line cap (as defined in the Revolving Facility) for a period of more than five
	consecutive Business Days or (ii)&nbsp;$5.0&nbsp;million. During a cash dominion period, the Company is required to comply with a consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio of not less than 1:00:1:00. The fixed charge coverage ratio is calculated on a
	consolidated basis for Lantheus Holdings and its subsidiaries on a trailing four fiscal quarter period basis, as (i)&nbsp;EBITDA (as defined in the agreement) minus capital expenditures minus certain restricted payments divided by (ii)&nbsp;interest
	plus taxes paid or payable in cash plus certain restricted payments made in cash plus scheduled principal payments paid or payable in cash. Upon an event of default, the lender has the right to declare the loans and other obligations outstanding
	immediately due and payable and all commitments immediately terminated or reduced, and the lender may, after such events of default, require LMI to make deposits with respect to any outstanding letters of credit in an amount equal to 105% of the
	greatest amount for which such letter of credit may be drawn.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financing Costs
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;30, 2015, LMI incurred and capitalized approximately $5.9&nbsp;million in debt issuance costs, consisting primarily of
	underwriting fees and expenses and legal fees in connection with the issuance of the Term Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, LMI incurred approximately $0.4&nbsp;million in fees and expenses, in connection with amendments under the previous facility, which are being amortized on a straight-line basis over the term of the Revolving Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	12. Stock-Based Compensation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Equity Incentive Plans
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s approved equity incentive plans included the 2015 Equity Incentive Plan (&#147;2015
	Plan&#148;), the 2013 Equity Incentive Plan (&#147;2013 Plan&#148;), and the 2008 Equity Incentive Plan (&#147;2008 Plan&#148;). These plans are administered by the Board of Directors and permit the granting of stock options, stock appreciation
	rights, restricted stock, restricted stock units and dividend equivalent rights (&#147;DERs&#148;) to employees, officers, directors and consultants of the Company. The Board of Directors may, at its sole discretion, grant DERs with respect to any
	award and such DER is treated as a separate award.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has certain stock option and restricted stock awards outstanding under
	each of its equity incentive plans but, upon adoption of the 2015 Plan, no longer grants new equity awards under its 2008 and 2013 Plans. The Company adopted its 2015 Plan in June 2015 and subsequently amended the plan in April 2016 to increase the
	common stock reserved under the plan by 2,140,000 shares to 4,555,277 shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	114
</P>
